commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):


1. Little crack  (4)
2. Play with one's food?  (6)(7)
3. What's holding up dessert?  (4)
4. Bud after Jack, perhaps?  (6)
5. Head of a noted animal rescue project  (4)


QUIP
DINNER THEATER
CONE
CHASER
NOAH
I done did the puzz in record time!
A nice nostalgic Monday. BARBIE was my generation's go-to doll, although my cousin also had RAGGEDY ANN and Andy.

Just to put you all on notice:
Today each of you is permitted a single shenanigan.
But you can also have one antic, one frolic, and one high jink.
Plan carefully!  Our Sam may be keeping track.

Just a quick note on cultural dissonance

I read the clue to 49A as 'Where Zed is in the alphabet", and spent a confused 15 seconds trying to figure out how to get England, Canada, or any short form of those to fit in 3 spaces, all while wondering why it wasn't clued to indicate a shortened form.

Then the penny dropped, and I realised the clue was about where in the alphabet the letter I call zed appears, not where in the world the letter you call zee is called zed. 

The mind is a funny place.
Well done! Thanks for a fun puzzle!

I enjoyed the puzzle, though referring to a single shenanigan (in 22D) caught my eye as well. 

Also, I think the revealer clue is worded in a misleading way, as it suggests taking the first part of the theme entries.  Something along the lines of "or how one might respond upon being introduced to 17-, 24-, 39-, and 50-Across" works better for me.

A perfect Monday puzzle for beginners?

Accessible revealer and theme.
Straightforward clues.
Hopefully familiar proper nouns (and fairly crossed too).
Minimal (if any) crosswordese.

No MESS, no SASS, no DISMAY. TRUE?

"Oh. you beautiful doll,
You great big, beautiful doll."

Nice trip down memory lane and nice way to start the week.

Thanks for the smiles.

The closest I have to a doll story isn't close at all.

I remember thinking when the GI Joe doll came out, I was glad I was too old for it.  I didn't want to be accused of playing with dolls, which in my childhood was a massive gender deviation.

I remember having an alien doll with exposed brains and a spaceman doll. Both died in a flaming UFO crash aided by plastic cement and barbecue lighter fluid. I was nine. My older brother was also a pyromaniac and offered useful conflagatory advice. (He became a firefighter, to my parents great relief.)
Crossword Revolution Day 20: NINA Nina Simone ‚Äî ‚ÄúEverything Must Change‚Äù https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vgX2EAdvFyw A CSD ‚Ñ¢ production.
To my mom‚Äôs, DISMAY I made a huge MESS by DYEING the hair of my life size BARBIE. Good times.

"This is just a line to buy dolls! You told me this was a cookout."
"No, I said it was a Barbie queue."

(I had to Ken-centrate for this one.)
I had a Cabbage Patch Doll and the Garbage Pail Kid cards

RAGGEDY ANN! üòç  She is the most special of memories. I still have my Raggedy Ann doll, which was made for me by a sick neighbor who I never got to know because she died before I was two,  but it is precious to me. 

I was also into Barbie for a while....  I vividly remember cutting up my mother's underwear to make Barbie and Skipper some special dresses. Mother wasn't impressed! Hahaha! I thought they were quite fancy evening gowns for them. I mean, not my fault we couldn't afford to buy a bunch of extra Barbie clothes. This is what you call creativity. Should have been rewarded! But not so...   üòÇ

Anyhow, a sweet and fun Monday puzzle!
Was this a hard Monday or did I just have too much to drink during the game? Enjoyed it, either way!

When I was about four years old, I gave tea parties for my dolls.  I was the last of five kids, so home alone with my mother, who was so swamped with housework she was never able to join us. Parties were held on the stair landing‚Äîjust enough space for the four of us‚Äîmy favorite, the patient girl doll I'd had my whole life (she had a new wig); the rather intimidatingly sophisticated, tall, young lady doll, in a pink taffeta dress that my father had won on a punchboard at his local bar; and a dark brown teddy bear, who seemed not quite to belong because he was a boy (all teddy bears are boys), but we tolerated him, even though he didn't say much.  

There wasn't any tea because we weren't old enough, so the cups had cornflakes in them (nobody would eat them for breakfast, but they were fine at teatime). It was lovely to spend time again in those innocent, uncomplicated times on Clinton Avenue in Des Moines.

Thank you Emily.  I had a wonderful time solving that delightful puzzle..  I never had any of those dolls, but I didn't mind.  I loved the ones I had. 

Life is always all about time, isn't it?

We had cabbage patch kids in our youth. Mine accidentally had its head split wide open, total accident I am sure. But there were events at the local mall where they had doll doctors or some other clever name. They would be dressed as doctors and fix up any hurt or fatally mauled dolls. So my half headed cabbage patch kids was sewn up along with a few other of my stuffies that also accidentally lost their heads.

I was seven years old when I witnessed the demise of my Barbie at the hands of my ten-year-old brother. 
I picked her up off the bedroom floor, her tummy cut wide open. "Why did you do this?" I cried. 
"Because I'm a doctor, and she needed surgery," he said. 
I pounced at him. "Well, if you're a doctor, close her up!"
"Not gonna happen," he answered with an evil smile, "That's beyond what I know how to do."
I'm not sure, but he must have gotten in trouble for playing with a knife. At least that's why I think he veered to computer programming instead!

It's nice to have a puzzle that brings up memories that make us laugh. 
Thank you for this, Ms. Rourke, as well as for making a puzzle that perfectly SATED that hunger for a breezy and fun grid. 
Considering the news, this was just what the, erm, *real* doctor ordered.
Did I miss a reference to Blythe here? The Kenner or Hasbro or

Hit a new record time with this puzzle and saw Raggedy Ann‚Äôs smiling face in my head as a reward. I was never too much for dolls, but the cozy features of Ann and her companion Andy meant they were constantly being tugged around by their soft arms and floppy legs.

As I recall, we had at some point both a Raggedy Ann and a Raggedy Andy when I was growing up, most likely after my sister was born, so sometime in the 1950s. My daughters were not much into the Barbie thing, but I'm pretty sure one was gifted to us. We certainly were aware of the Cabbage Patch Kids, but my youngest was interested and invested in a couple of the American Girl dolls. We ended up giving them to the local library for their toy library when we moved to Florida.

A very nice Monday puzzle, thanks, Emily.

A little bit slower for me today, but great puzzle nonetheless. 

I‚Äôm not all too familiar with my vintage dolls lol. Never even heard of American Girl and Raggedy Ann took me way too long.
My first try for 17 A was Testa Rossa, the classic Ferrari model. Guess what my favorite toys were.
Very satisfying Monday solve

Delightful romp. Although I never had any of these dolls I remember other children having them. I was blessed with Tiny Tears and little Rukkas and some generic dolls.

This one was a joy to solve.

Dolls were never my thing.  I did end up with a Barbie at some point, though.  She was subjected to indignities I will not go into here.  

I wasn't a total miscreant.  My stuffed animals were treated very well.

Now I know totally and completely and forever, what BAMA is. No need to include it again, I've got it!
I barely needed to think twice during this entertaining and very agreeable crossword (I find my self drifting towards 'easy-breezy' and 'fun' but am resisting).
Despite never have seen a RAGGEDY ANNE or an AMERICAN GIRL, never had a BARBIE (I had baby dollies) and my sons didn't want CABBAGE PATCH KIDS, it all came right easily.
I couldn't understand at first why Mme didn't fit the Madam Doubtfire clue, but that was the book, and why armour didn't work. 
Excellent.
I only remember having a baby doll and trying to treat her like a real baby.  I can‚Äôt  remember what I named her; this would have been the early 40‚Äôs.   Fun Monday puzzle.

Nice Monday puzzle. None of the theme answers dawned on me just from the clues, but everything came together with some crosses. Really enjoyed it. 

Looked up Ms. Rourke's two previous puzzles and both were similarly cute and enjoyable. One was a Tuesday from January 10, 2023. Answers in that one: 

PINKPANTHER
TONYTHETIGER
COWARDLYLION
CHESIRECAT
And the 'reveal':
HELLOKITTY

Looking forward to more.

One more puzzle find that I'll put in a reply. 

.....

Strands Thread.


Strands #344
‚ÄúThe munchies‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ

Serve no spoilers until after the View All Replies button please. 

Sorry late to post.  Was up late watching a sporting event.  

No THC required.
a fun monday puzzle with a cute theme!

Sweet to uncover the beautiful GLAD I ASKED, then to later learn that it‚Äôs never appeared in a Times puzzle before.  Great find!  

Sweet to course through the puzzle‚Äôs schwa-de-vivre with its ten answers ending in that sound ‚Äì BALSA, BAMA, NINA, DATA, MICA, ARENA, HENNA, SIGMA, SIA, and TO A.

Sweet to work my brain, trying to figure out the revealer without looking at its clue.  I failed, but my brain was glad for the trying.  

So, I read the clue, uncovered the revealer's first letter, then BAM the answer came with a happy-burst from simultaneously cracking the riddle, seeing the DOLLY pun, and the funny thought of saying ‚ÄúHello, Dolly‚Äù to a doll.

That was a sweet moment.

One answer triggered a sweet memory of how my older sister and I, as little kids, got a big kick out of funny-sounding words. When we heard one, we‚Äôd look at each other with mirth in our eyes; it was our little secret.  And BOSOM, to us, was one of the funniest-sounding words of all. 

Sweetness in the box today for me ‚Äì a lovely gift.  Thank you so much for coming up with this, Emily.

Not for the squeamish: Every Thanksgiving for years we had the annual Barbie Shoot in Moab UT. We made dioramas and all sorts of devices upon or within we could place a Barbie or a Ken. Throughout the year we would buy "Barbie Lots" from the Salvation Army, etc. 

In the fullness of time it became the social event of the season as we celebrated thanksgiving with bullets, bombs and, of course, Barbie.

Thanks Emily for the trip down memory lane

Agree with everyone else that this was a great Monday crossword - no major stand-out difficulties, but plenty of nice clues and answers to kick off the week. A few minutes under my Monday average :)
Many thanks Emily!

No Chatty Cathy? or Kewpie?

I flew through this puzzle. But I never had any of these dolls. I eventually got a Tammy doll, as she was more wholesome than anatomically absurd Barbie. And I had a Betsy McCall doll.
Made them a few outfits, but never did much else with dolls.

When was the last time you ever heard a foot-long sandwich referenced by its full name? SUBMARINE! I had to let the crosses fill that in!

Fun puzzle, Emily.
When she was a little girl she had a rag doll.... And she grew up to be Tina Turner. https://youtu.be/CCM_JGrv8UI?si=YBvMma1BNTxo-TEa

Never heard of ICE IT, are the alleged wonder fruit du jour, ACAI, so finished this one on a best-guess at the C in the cross. 
For me, YOYO stands for "You're On Your Own", so that was a puzzle. Fortunately I had LYS in the cross (never encountered the LiS version mentioned by Sam in the blog), so didn't compound the problem.

Enjoyable solve, despite a certain amount of premonitory despair when the theme became evident.

Sorry to say, this puzzle makes two in a row that didn't grab me.  Not that there was anything wrong with it, and because it's a Monday, it was always going to be a quick romp anyway, but I didn't get much excitement from it.

This is probably not because of the puzzle per se, but rather because I have no interest in dolls.  As a kid, I never understood what the attraction of playing with dolls was. I was involved in games and sports that had a competitive edge and that allowed you to become more skilled in them.  Dolls just seemed like something to carry around with you.

Of course, I have no objection to anyone playing with dolls, but I think our innate nature as a species dictates that they will always be more widely enjoyed by girls more than boys.  (Note: "our innate nature as a species" allows that there will be exceptions.) Despite our more enlightened society of the 2020s, I'm sure that far more girls still play with dolls than boys.

And similarly, far more grownup women find a crossword about dolls more interesting than do grownup men.  At least this one...

Well, the next one is just 13 hours away...

Fun puzzle!  Thank you, Emily!

emu food
more emu food

I was never interested in Barbies or Cabbagepatch Kids, but I do have fond memories of my childhood Raggedy Ann doll. I think I still have her, boxed away somewhere.  I also have an American Girl horse with all the accessories (never owned an AG doll though!) üòÑ

This was an enjoyable romp through nostalgia.
there were too many rerun entries from the last week or so.  Which is getting to be frequent.  Not only same words but sameclues for them.
I had a handmade raggedy Ann, and the very first Barbie. My daughter had a cabbage patch kid and an American Girl doll. Lovely memories today‚Äîsometimes it‚Äôs more than a puzzle.

Are these defective?

irani should be iranian
nulls (as a verb) is questionable

fleur de LIS, not ‚Ä¶ lys

Challenged, anyone?

Our fourth puzzle in a row that felt much too easy.  (When 1-Across is BALSA. you know you're in for a smooth ride. And how many times have we had BAMA in the last week?)

Nothing wrong with this puzzle; the theme is nice, if a bit obvious. Just a little too BLAH. 

It's Monday.  What did you expect?
I'm just looking for something that gets my "little grey cells" working in the morning.

Unsurprisingly the only DOLL in this group I‚Äôm aware of is BARBIE. I had a Sindy, which I think was the British response to Barbie. No idea what, if any, differences there were. My Mum used to make her clothes for me. I had the best dressed doll in the school.

I think Mr Shortz is on a mission to incorporate crimson tide/BAMA into as many puzzles as possible. I‚Äôve gone from Who? to Oh, them again in a very short space of time.

Nice Monday puzzle. Nothing BLAH about the solve.

I've been watching the ANTICs from last night in Philly, and just wow! The mayor asked folks not to climb the city's light poles, so they tore them down instead, and carried them through the streets. Next level shenanigans.
Just over four minutes from balsa to dimes.  Thanks, Emily!

I thwarted all  my educated, professional parents' efforts to direct me toward a non-traditional female role in the 60's & 70's.
I was a little girl who played dolls, and had a very involved pretend life. Raggedy Ann was a big part, but also baby dolls.   (No Barbie - my parents scorned plastic.)
I played house and always was the mother. Cooked and baked starting at age 9. Babysat early. 
I was academically "gifted", but my dream was to be a housewife and mother. It came true, and I LOVED every minute of it. 
Thanks for letting me reminisce.

Hi everyone! My wife and I enjoyed today's puzzle. Yes it was easier than other Mondays, but the topic was refreshing. Although I am a man, I am a "girl dad".  I recall the days of my daughter playing with Samantha (American Doll). I also recall my mother and my Aunt (both from the Silent Generation) bemoaning the fact that my daughter would leave her Barbie lying around without clothes! Now my daughter has a baby of her own and I await sharing the play toys that our new grandson will play with naked or not! Thank you Emily and Sam for the memories!!!!!

I had a very large family of dolls; none of them were named RAGGEDY-anything (although we did have Johnny Gruelle's book with its enchanting illustrations and a much larger cast of characters vs this puzzle.)  Anyway....my sister (older by 4 years) outgrew her dolls and was a neglectful 'mother,' so her dolls were "re-homed" and became my responsibility.  

There was "Tickle-me Elmo" when my kids were small, at a price we couldn't afford, and of course I was not going to buy a BARBIE doll.  (Available earlier than this puzzle claims, an only-child spoiled brat four houses down on May Avenue had the first BARBIE any of us ever saw:  1957/58.  It was about as far from a 'baby-doll' as you could get. )  I vowed that we would be a BARBIE-FREE ZONE...and then  PhysicsDaughter received a BARBIE at her 4th or 5th birthday party, which end-run of course outsmarted Old Mom...but I could see that a doll who fit into a pocket was an asset, so, oh well.

Our nursery-school fund-raiser made quite a bit of money selling clothes for CABBAGE-PATCH KIDs, along with doll-beds and little quilts.  Ah, memories.  
Do kids still get dollies?

I think it was yesterday that Vaer posted about the Ladies and Gentlemen 50 years of SNL Music special. Not sure why I hadn‚Äôt heard of this, but I happen to have Peacock and gave it a look. It is really quite remarkable. Not suggesting that people run out to subscribe to this, Vaer mentioned a free trial perhaps. You can see the trailer here. https://tinyurl.com/3ztsfhah

I saw a production of HELLODOLLY in Pittsburgh back in the 80s; my father was playing cello in the orchestra. The male lead was Barry Williams, aka Greg from The Brady Bunch. His singing was a bit on the flat side to my ear.

Regarding the dolls in this puzzle, I've owned all of them except for AMERICANGIRL. But my favorite memories are of the dolls my grandmother made; she was an excellent seamstress.

No one seems to remember the finest US doll maker of them all - Madam Alexander, the go-to doll of the 1940s and 1950s. They had the sweetest faces and most sensible cloths.  I remember being horrified when the anorexic Barbie was introduced and glad I had carefully preserved my own dolls so my daughter never had to own one of those ridiculous skinny monstrosities. Many happy memories of both of us sharing with friends and dressing the dolls for different activities. Mme Alexander also made dolls that tied in with classic books - Cinderella and Alice in Wonderland were two that I owned, thanks to an indulgent grandfather who liked to shop for toys at FAO Schwartz. I also have fond memories of the soft and huggable Raggedy Ann.

If you want to carve a Naomi Campbell doll,
is it okay to use BALSA,
or do you need a supermodel dolly wood?

(Asking for an American girlfriend)
Nice Monday puzzle to reboot my brain.  At 6:33, I came within 45 seconds of my best time.
Well, he didn't lead the Chiefs to (one more) Superbowl victory, but he knows how to treat a Girl right: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=cn154emMguQ NSFW! NSFW!

Monday‚Äôs Monday. 

This one held me up in a few spots that had multiple possible answers and where I guessed wrong, so I ended up with a relatively sluggish 6m11s (I have a Monday best of 3m40s due to one really ridiculously easy one that just makes going for speed pointless). 

But as with all crosswords, I appreciate the ability to make one at all. I‚Äôve never done it.
Shocked by the use of the less common fleur-de-lys spelling with no added commentary that they would be using it (e.g. "fleur-de-__, less commonly") especially for a Monday. Brought down my time.

Nice memories from today's puzzle. Three uncles were WWII vets and I remember fighting with my brother over a GI Joe doll. Later on 2 daughters had Barbie & Ken and Cabbage Patch kids. Christmas season always included a trip to NYC for visits to FAO Schwartz & Radio City Music Hall. Started the puzzle early this morning then ran out to take my wife to the train with maybe one or two blanks remaining. Returned after gym & grocery stops to find the clock still running. Personal Monday "high" of over 5 hours!
If you want metaphors, read Tom Robbins.  Page 1 of Skinny Legs and All-  "wolf mother wallpaper".

When I was very young I would sometimes play with a girl who lived next door to my grandfather. She had a fairly creepy doll called Saranade [sic] that was equipped with a speaker. She knew I hated the doll, so took delight in plaguing me with the doll's songs. I still remember: "Saranade, Saranade, that's my name, I can walk, I can talk, and play with you, a game or two ... 
Aside from the creepy memory, this was an easy one to take. I matched my best time to the second.
My final blank was on square 57, having ARTI_ and _CRU. One was a proper noun and the other was a word I've never heard of, so I just started spamming the alphabet until I landed on E.
First time under 10 minutes. No lookups.

There are lots of horror movies about creepy dolls, but perhaps the most disturbing is Todd Haynes' 1987 film Superstar: The Karen Carpenter Story (wiki link below) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superstar:_The_Karen_Carpenter_Story fast solve typical Monday, but I agree with the observation that the memories and anecdotes in today's comments are rich.
I loved this puzzle!  I think it‚Äôs perfect for a Monday, and has lots of fun and interesting clue-and answer combinations.  I also thought the doll theme was clever and good.
What's up with BAMA appearing in so many puzzles lately?
Its almost as if not having a gimmick is now a gimmick.

That was fun! I finished in less than half of my average time, and was just under 30 seconds away from beating my best time. I loved American Girl dolls when I was growing up - Team Josefina! Thanks for a great puzzle, fellow Emily :)

This was fun! ARTIE / ECRU was hard but nothing a little keyboard smashing couldn't fix. 48D was quite clever, loved getting that one.

As our summer season ends, South Pole Crossword Club wants to thank you for keeping us entertained at the bottom of the world! Although I haven't been able to post much, we've been solving every week. Crossword Club has made friends out of people that otherwise may not have spent time together-- what a beautiful gift!

I was very, very late to the puzzle today, returning home from a stressful afternoon fairly annoyed at anything and everything. Then this puzzle -- such a blessing! Really joyful, and it just flowed. Best one in days! 

I enjoyed this little run of vowels: SIA, TO A, IOU. I liked the intentionality of doubling up on PlayStation. Plus, the (I think PuzzPair¬Æ?) of EBB and EDDY, resonating in both form and content, made me feel I was channeling @Lewis during my solve! And the top of the grid felt positively international with the Persian, the Greek and the South Asian trio of downs. 

Most of all, there were all the cues to childhood! Beyond the dolls, there were model airplanes and cartoons at 1A/1D, an Easter egg hunt, films from my youth (and tv: Bosom Buddies-!)... All in good fun. Thanks, Emily!

Despite the fact it's unlikely anyone will see this so late on Monday night, I really have to post about the image on the Wordplay column! I even scanned through the day's comments, but don't see anyone else on this topic today. @Sam Corbin's choice of seals gave me a flashback to one of the oddest commercials that ran during the Superbowl last night. Disturbingly, the musician Seal's head was superimposed on an actual seal! Singing, of course, a modified version of his biggest hit, "Kiss from a Rose"... This article says it all (and has a link to the ad spot): Seal Is a Literal Seal in Taika Waititi‚Äôs Mountain Dew Super Bowl Commercial https://variety.com/2025/tv/musicians/seal-literal-seal-taika-waititi-mountain-dew-super-bowl-commercial-1236301481/ Councidence?? üßêüòÇ

@Lewis

Dinner Theater indeed. I got it trouble once before for having the audacity to reply to you, but dinner theater is in my wheelhouse and the source of some of my best friends. Not to mention steamed peas. Mine was Paradise Playhouse in Excelsior Springs, MO. I was Barefoot in the Park there and the owner died from Arsenic and Old Lace (actually just drank himself to death  backstage).
@Eddie I almost did but got hung up on Feur de lis sic lys, as I never did the crossing answer, so I spent time searching for my error!

@Liz B Though a girl, I never could figure out how to play with dolls, but Barbie dolls were the worst.  My best friend had a large collection and I remember stitting there glumly wondering what on earth I was supposed to do.  I had more luck with Raggedy Ann, whom I would prop up next to me and then read stories to her.

@Cat Lady Margaret 
Oh boy....I hope everyone reports back tomorrow.  I have a few ideas
@Cat Lady Margaret If I keep to a low jink, can I please have an additional antic?

Cat Lady Margaret,

A single monkeyshine?
Horsefeather.

Cat Lady

Fiddlestick.

@Cat Lady Margaret 

Kudo, Cat Lady, this was a brilliant collection!
@Cat Lady Margaret  The singular "antic" reminds me of Bill Bryson writing about words in English for which there seem to exist only the negated form.   "She is so wonderfully competent and ept"

@Charlie 
Yep. How about this?
After successful contract negotiations, most employees were gruntled.
Some may be nonplussed by that sentence, but if you get the joke, are you plussed? And if you are nonchalant about singular "antic," are others chalant?

@CalGal 

I must say, I'm mayed!

@dutchiris 
LOL
@Grumpy What a funny night to choose the phrase ‚Äúthe penny dropped‚Äù!

@deborah 

"The penny dropped" meaning sudden understanding (often after a period of confusion0

has an interesting history.  Different British sources refer to 

‚óò a coin-operated phone (1939), which activated after the penny placed in the slot "dropped" to the sensor ‚Äî and often failed to

‚óò or, more distressingly, to the door to a pay toilet.

Meanwhile, I thought it referenced coins turning on the heat in your flat for a certain amount of time.

@confused_indivdual 
For a long time public toilets needed a penny in a slot in the door. So we have 'I need to spend a penny' and 'the penny dropped.'

Richard,

Interesting take on "introductions" in the revealer clue. Having filled in all the themers before getting to the revealer, I had no doubt what it meant. I read your comment, and could not recall the word "introduction" in a revealer referring to the first parts of theme entries. I checked xwordinfo.com; it never has.
@Elmer Borden ü§£üòÅüòÇ

@Puzzlemucker 

Nice. I don‚Äôt think I had heard that one before.

@Puzzlemucker 

Poignantly gorgeous.
@Mike You outdid yourself today. One verbal high jink above past entries.

@Andrzej 

That's so sad (and downright mean) that the new owner would choose to keep what wasn't rightfully his and your fox along with it. I'm very sorry. Children get very attached to their dolls or stuffed animals and should be the ones allowed to make the decision of when to let them go, if ever.

@Andrzej 

Wow, Andrzej, you just scared the living heck out of me.

It seems the world, even the so-called first world, isn't nearly as cozy as the world I spent all of my life in.

That may be the most sobering thought I've had in years.  I may go into an extended period of readjustment.

@Andrzej 

The new owner sounds who wouldn't let you recover a box of toys narsty.

Did you consider doing something
‚óÑconflagatory‚ñ∫
(New To Me, hat tip to ùë¨ùíçùíéùíÜùíì ùë©ùíêùíìùíÖùíÜùíè) about it?

[Czesz]

@Andrzej 

My very first job--a co-worker had immigrated from Poland around the end of the 80's and I asked her about her experience coming to the US.  She said  her most striking moment was walking into a grocery store (no guards, no line!) absolutely filled with food, free to buy something, anything.  She said she'd never forget it.  That to her was freedom.

@The Poet McTeagle 

My parents experienced the same when they visited Paris in the 1970s: shops filled with stuff!

@Andrzej 

Thanks for sharing. How sad that the new owner wouldn't give you back the boxes of toys. Surely, he could see the value was sentimental not monetary but in the environment you describe, I suppose people go to their basest inclinations to get by for themselves and their family, their number ones. 

A saying I internalized while going through some very deep difficulties in my life is "Hurt people hurt people."  I try to remember that when someone is hurtful to me... often it's because they are also hurting. It was easy to see in that particular difficulty (ultimately unsuccessful years-long roller coaster of infertility treatments) because I was in a small community of women going through it but we are all different people and in varying stages of success and not success. It was the worst time of my life.  I'm not suggesting *by any means* that it's akin to Poland in the 90s‚Äîmore so about the nature of a group of people in a very awful situation. 

I mean, it was no "Lord of the Flies," but still. 

Of course, someone could also just be a jerk.... 
 but I tend to prefer to give grace in my judgements until otherwise informed. :-D 

In any case, I'm so glad that you've come back as a society from that time‚Äînot only having recovered but now thriving. That's lovely!! And you do give me hope in these dark days here in the U.S.  <3

@Andrzej 

Thank you for the context; with the new understanding, I change my assessment to just sad and not necessarily mean. 

I know what you speak of, not from first-person experience, but through being present, in 1988, at a Russian refugee couple's first trip to a U.S. supermarket. 
Their eyes glistened, their jaws dropped, and they couldn't contain themselves as they picked up every fruit and every fresh vegetable, smelling them and practically squealing like children in a toy store. Their awe and happiness was a beautiful sight to see.

@Constant Reader 

Thank you for the story üôÇ

Could you please explain "There wasn't any tea because we weren't old enough"?

Over here in my lifetime kids have always been served tea. In fact, tea has been the default hot drink for people of all ages in Poland. Coffee seems to be an adult-only thing though, or adult and young adult, these days.

I visited Sweden in my early twenties, and stayed with my mother's childhood friend: a Jewish-Polish emigree, and her wonderful Swedish husband. They introduced me to Swedish culture, including coffee drinking for people of all ages.

Does the US have a similar taboo against children drinking tea as Poland has regarding coffee?

@Constant Reader, I am not Constant Reader. That was somewhere else, about something else.  

Here, I am dutchiris‚Äîalways have been before and will be again.  Next time I will pay more attention to where I am when I post.

@Andrzej 

When I was four years old, we were in the depths of the Great Depression, and tea and coffee (my mother's preference) were hard to come by.  I remember drinking tea later, but we had more of everything then. I don't really know how it played out in other homes, what the culture was like.

@Constant Reader

Just be you, whoever you are. We love you all the same.

@Constant Reader 

For us, as a family - but for most Polish people in general - the early 1990s were a time of financial crisis. The old regime and its economy had only just collapsed, and it took quite a few years for the benefits of democracy and market economy to kick in. Some who went into business and capitalized on the transition struck gold, but most common people suffered. There were two or three years then that - as my mother much later admitted, to my horror - we barely had any money for food. I have no idea how my parents managed to take care of our family without me realizing just how bad things were - it must have taken incredible effort, and I am very grateful to them for taking care of me as they did. Ca. 1993 they started new careers and before long we were doing OK.

@Andrzej 

In general, tea drinking is not common in the US. Coffee is the preferred morning stimulant.
Exceptions would be families hailing from Britain, India, and China.
And sweet tea in the South, which is more like iced sugar water than tea.

Coffee and tea are adult drinks, not usually served to children. But that has loosened up considerably in the past 30 years with teenagers flocking to coffee shop culture, as commercialized by Starbucks.

@Andrzej 
In our household in the 1930s, it was accepted that the utilities were cut off because my parents couldn't pay the bill, that the coal delivery might be late, that we often had plain white rice with milk and some raisins for lunch ‚Äîthat's just the way things were. When my favorite uncle brought us baskets of food into town from his farm, it was incredibly exciting to have as much to eat as you wanted at suppertime.  

The Great Depression was worse in the big cities, and at least in the Midwest, we were in the heart of the farmland, but extreme poverty was common all over the country, and we didn't have the social programs that we have had since FDR introduced them. 

Once I met a man who said his family was never so well off as during the Depression; it was the only time they'd had a yacht.  He said his father was a lawyer and he had a lot of wealthy clients.

@dutchiris 

Obviously my life thousands of kilometers away and 45 years later was very different than yours, but it's amazing there still are some similarities. My father was born in a village north of Warsaw, and having family there helped in the 1980s when the "communist" economy was in crisis (that is, in more of a crisis than usual): meat was especially hard to come by, but my grandfather would occasionally source us a whole calf from one of his neighbors. My maternal grandmother in Warsaw had a huge freezer which we loaded with portions of meat to last for months.

@Andrzej 

Extraordinary luck for your family!

@Andrzej 

I feel that the newer the science or technology, the less "fitted" are those pioneers. 

When I first started programming in 2000, I already had a previous career in physics/chemistry.   Instead of Herr Doktor I was just Frank, the old guy.

I was pretty much "Frank, the old guy" right up to my retirement.  Most of those I worked with had never encountered someone retiring from programming, as it was such a new field.

I used to say that I've met five Nobel prize winners, and none of them were as arrogant as the average programmer.  

But I think that's changed as the field has matured.

At least that's my story.

Good call - yes, I think in some ways he was a misfit. 

He became a wonderful brother to me, but back then he wasn't just a misfit, but also a smarty-pants with an inclination to rattle his little sister. 
Case in point: between "being" a doctor and becoming a computer architect/programmer, he decided he "was" a mechanical engineer.

@Oikofuge 

ACAI had never been used until 2010, when it was clued as an [Exotic berry in some fruit juices].  But it has appeared 110 times since then.  It's one you will see again and again.  

LIS has appeared 173 times in total, compared to 119 for LYS.  In fact, [Fleur-de-___] has clued LIS nearly 100 times!  (That clue has only clued LYS a bit over 20 times.)  It's a true "kealoa", so always be aware that the middle letter varies.

Both of these things are common entries; I had the impression you were more experienced than that!

I hope you didn‚Äôt get the impression I was chastising you. Just pointing out that these two examples are very common fill here. 

American crosswords and the British cryptics you‚Äôre familiar with are two completely different beasts that bear a striking resemblance, much like horses and donkeys. The NYT runs a cryptic every six or eight weeks in the printed paper (also available at xwordinfo,com for a membership fee). I‚Äôve tried a few and I‚Äôve learned (1) I‚Äôm capable of doing them, and (2) I truly can‚Äôt stand them. They require a kind of thinking exercise I just don‚Äôt care for. 

Others, of course, are free to disagree, and undoubtedly will.

@Steve L 

I could write a long reply but maybe a short one will be enough: I enjoyed this puzzle about dolls much more than I would one about sports, and the comments today are some of the best I've seen on this board: human interest galore.

Also, as a boy I did not enjoy sports or competitions, and I would probably have played with dolls, if society didn't specifically target them at girls, and discourage boys from playing with them.

What's so different about toy soldiers, GI Joe and dolls btw? Other than societal gender profiling that is?
@Steve L You sound like someone who would benefit from a quick listen to "William Wants a Doll" from "Free to Be You and Me". https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lshobg1Wt2M

@Pax Ahimsa Gethen 

How much more clearly could I have said that I have no objection to anyone playing with dolls, and that there will be exceptions?

@Steve L 

Dolls and stuffed animals were my friends, not just things I carried around.  We had parties and played games and I could read to them. Playing with dolls fosters social skills, imagination, empathy, and caring for others. None of which would naturally appeal to a young boy unless they were taught fun ways to play with dolls. I know you aren't saying anything against dolls, rather sharing your experience as a kid. 

I have an honorary niece (who I adore), who is here with her mom a lot, and she carries her baby doll. Sometimes the doll feels sick or is hurt and little Bevie get sad and wonders how to help. Fortunately, I have a medical degree in doll doctoring from the University of HeathieJ, so Dr. HeathieJ to the rescue!! Bevie frets about her doll until I assure her she's all better and then she takes extra good care of her and then has a little party with her dinos and other dolls.

But we know that these "softer"/social type skills were traditionally encouraged more in girls than boys, of course. Just as competition and athleticism was traditionally more encouraged with boys. As an adult, I personally wish that I'd been more encouraged to be athletic and competitive‚Äîas well as playing with dolls‚Äîbut we were very traditional, so my brothers did boy things and I did girl things. 

These days, I think that is changing somewhat. I like to see that little Bevie is also quite athletic and likes to race and such, so I see more well-roundedness there and I love it!

@Steve L It sounds like you don't have much experience with how children actually play with dolls. They are primarily imaginative toys, not objects that are just "carried around." Playing with dolls allows children to practice empathy and communication, model interpersonal interactions, and create imaginative stories. Consider the parallels between making up a story about the lives and interpersonal conflicts of a collection of dolls and writing a novel or screenplay about the lives and interpersonal conflicts of a set of invented characters. Interpersonal and creative abilities are valuable skills for all adults.

@Pax Ahimsa Gethen 

William Wants a Doll! I loved that story and hadn't thought of it in forever. Thinking about it brings back such clear images in my memory, all these decades later. As does "Free to Be You and Me" -- not just the album cover, but the area at school where we got to listen to it when I was in second grade. Thanks for that!
@Janine I also have fond memories of my Raggedy Ann! Also my Hollie Hobby dolls, which were of similar construction. My mom saved those so I still have them.
